newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine Danube shipper recovering, seeks investor.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine Danube shipper recovering, seeks investor.

text.p: Ukraine's Danube Shipping Company (UDASCO), once one of the river's biggest carriers, has started seeking foreign investors as it moves to recover from sanctions against Belgrade -- once its main trading partner.
"We must find a strategic investor. That is what we are doing now very actively," UDASCO President Petro Suvorov told Reuters late on Thursday at the port of Izmail, where UDASCO is based.

"In name we are a shareholding company but in fact we are a 100 percent state-owned enterprise because parliament has included us on a list of strategic enterprises which cannot be privatised," Suvorov said on Friday.
"But when we find a strategic, investor it would not be a problem to change the status de facto," he added.
Suvorov, appointed president last month, said estimates for necessary strategic foreign investments were $100-200 million.

UDASCO, running 55 ocean-faring vessels and 850 river ships, boats and barges with a total deadweight capacity of 1.2 million tonnes, shipped 40 million tonnes of cargo on the Danube and worldwide last year.
But about 40 per cent of shipping capacity went unused for the company, which also owns five cruise ships.

"Our hopes are pinned on a Danube shipping boom once sanctions against Yugoslavia, which have been lifted, become a reality," Suvorov said, referring to the 1992/95 international sanctions against Belgrade.
The nearby Port of Reni has been working at a quarter of its 12-million-tonne annual capacity, Izmail at half of its nine million tonne capacity, with tiny Ust-Dunaisk working least.

"Customers have found other ways to ship than traditional ones. To avoid the Yugoslav stretch of the Danube via Slovenia, there is the new Danube-Rhine channel with railways. It's not Ukraine's problem but the Danube's problem -- the amount of cargo shipped has been halved since 1991," Suvorov said.
He added there had been increased competition from Germany, Dutch and Russian shipping companies.
Suvorov said hopes of quick economic growth in the former Yugoslavia, once one of the former Soviet Union's biggest trade partners, had also been dashed.
In Soviet days, Ukraine traded $2 billion annually with the former Yugoslavia but currently the trade figure with rump-Yugoslavia stands at only $40 million.
But Suvorov said in 1994 UDASCO, which employs 9,800 people, built four 4,000-tonne sea cargo ships and 60 new barges using credits from Portugese and Austrian banks.
UDASCO revenues during the first four months of this year stood at $40 million, he added.

Its management has also pinned hopes on the new Prorva five-metre-deep channel from the Danube to the Black Sea to shorten the distance to Izmail and attract larger sea-going ships to Ukraine's stretch of the Danube instead of Romania's.
He said the channel would open by the end of the year with $6 million in investments, adding another $40 million project foresaw upgrading other channels to a depth of seven metres.
